```bash
sudo mkdir -p /home/computeruse/github/palios-taey-nova
sudo chown $(whoami) /home/computeruse/github/palios-taey-nova
```

2. Now, let's create a symbolic link from your actual directory to the one Claude DC expects:

```bash
ln -s /home/jesse/projects/palios-taey-nova/claude-dc-implementation /home/computeruse/github/palios-taey-nova/claude-dc-implementation
```

This will create a "shortcut" so that when Claude DC's code looks for files in `/home/computeruse/github/palios-taey-nova/claude-dc-implementation`, it will actually find them in your `/home/jesse/projects/palios-taey-nova/claude-dc-implementation` directory.

3. Once that's set up, we can create the necessary directories in your actual location:

```bash
mkdir -p /home/jesse/projects/palios-taey-nova/claude-dc-implementation/config
mkdir -p /home/jesse/projects/palios-taey-nova/claude-dc-implementation/data/transcripts
```

4. Copy your secrets file to the expected location:

```bash

cp /home/jesse/secrets/palios-taey-secrets.json /home/jesse/projects/palios-taey-nova/claude-dc-implementation/credentials/service_account.json
```

5. Now let's run the transcript processor:

```bash
cd /home/jesse/projects/palios-taey-nova/claude-dc-implementation
python3 process_transcripts.py
```

This setup preserves Claude DC's original code and design while redirecting the paths to work in your environment. When Claude DC returns, everything will be just as he expects it!
